resource descriptions.descriptionText: Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) is a catalog of human genes and genetic disorders. Each entry has a summary of related medical articles. It is meant for health care professionals and researchers. OMIM is maintained by Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine.
PubMed is a searchable database of medical literature and lists journal articles that discuss Wrinkly skin syndrome. Click on the link to view a sample search on this topic.
Morava E, Guillard M, Lefeber DJ, Wevers RA. Autosomal recessive cutis laxa syndrome revisited. Eur J Hum Genet. 2009 Sep;17(9):1099-110.

To find a medical professional who specializes in genetics, you can ask your doctor for a referral or you can search for one yourself. Online directories are provided by the American College of Medical Genetics and the National Society of Genetic Counselors. If you need additional help, contact a GARD Information Specialist. You can also learn more about genetic consultations from Genetics Home Reference.

The Genetic Testing Registry (GTR) provides information about the genetic tests for this condition. The intended audience for the GTR is health care providers and researchers. Patients and consumers with specific questions about a genetic test should contact a health care provider or a genetics professional.

The National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) has a report for patients and families about this condition. NORD is a patient advocacy organization for individuals with rare diseases and the organizations that serve them.
Orphanet is a European reference portal for information on rare diseases and orphan drugs. Access to this database is free of charge.

GeneReviews provides current, expert-authored, peer-reviewed, full-text articles describing the application of genetic testing to the diagnosis, management, and genetic counseling of patients with specific inherited conditions.
MeSH® (Medical Subject Headings) is a terminology tool used by the National Library of Medicine. Click on the link to view information on this topic.

The Monarch Initiative brings together data about this condition from humans and other species to help physicians and biomedical researchers. Monarch’s tools are designed to make it easier to compare the signs and symptoms (phenotypes) of different diseases and discover common features. This initiative is a collaboration between several academic institutions across the world and is funded by the National Institutes of Health. Visit the website to explore the biology of this condition.
Arora P, Chakravarty P, Khanna D, Gupta R. Cutis laxa autosomal recessive type II or wrinkly skin syndrome?. Indian Dermatol Online J. 2016 Sep-Oct; 7(5):440-442.

overviewQuestion.answerText: Wrinkly skin syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by sagging or wrinkly skin, reduced skin elasticity, and delayed closure of the fontanel (a baby's "soft spot" on the top of his/her head). Other associated signs and symptoms vary widely. Case reports suggest that this condition is often inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion. It can be caused by mutations in the ATP6VOA2 gene. Wrinkly skin syndrome appears to be represent the mild version of autosomal recessive cutis laxa syndrome type 2.[4476][12629][12630]

basicQuestions.questionText: Do the signs and symptoms of wrinkly skin syndrome change as a person ages? What is the long term outlook for people with wrinkly skin syndrome?
basicQuestions.answerText: Unfortunately much of what is known regarding wrinkly skin syndrome comes from individual case reports. There is very limited information regarding the long term outlook for people with this syndrome. Also there can be great variability of symptoms, particularly regarding growth delay, developmental delay, and neurological abnormalities. Some affected individuals have developed seizures and mental deterioration later in life.[4477] Skin symptoms may become milder with age.[4476][4477]

references.authors: Morava E, Guillard M, Lefeber DJ, Wevers RA
references.articleTitle: Autosomal recessive cutis laxa syndrome revisited.

references.authors: Kornak U et al.,
references.articleTitle: Impaired glycosylation and cutis laxa caused by mutations in the vesicular H+-ATPase subunit ATP6V0A2

basicQuestions.questionText: What are the signs and symptoms of wrinkly skin syndrome?
basicQuestions.answerText:
Common signs and symptoms of wrinkly skin syndrome include wrinkled and inelastic skin on the face, backs of hands, tops of feet, and abdomen, and delayed closure of the fontanel (a baby's "soft spot" on the top of his/her head).[4476][12629][12630] Additional signs and symptoms that have been described in individual cases, include:[4476][12630]

Small head size (microcephaly)
Unusual facial characteristics 
Downslanting eyes
Delayed motor development
Intellectual disability
Hip dislocation
Joint laxity, subluxation (a tendon slips out of its normal position)
Hernias
Growth delay

Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) lists additional signs and symptoms that have been described in people with wrinkly skin syndrome.

references.authors: Morava E, Guillard M, Lefeber DJ, Wevers RA
references.articleTitle: Autosomal recessive cutis laxa syndrome revisited.

references.authors: Van Maldergem L, Dobyns W, Kornak U
references.articleTitle: ATP6V0A2-Related Cutis Laxa

references.authors: Arora P, Chakravarty P, Khanna D, Gupta R
references.articleTitle: Cutis laxa autosomal recessive type II or wrinkly skin syndrome?

basicQuestions.answerText: In many cases the underlying genetic cause of wrinkly skin syndrome is not known.[12634] Some cases are caused by mutations in the ATP6VOA2 gene.[4476][12629][12630] These gene mutations result in an abnormality in glycosylation.[4476][12629] Glycosylation is a chemical process that occurs in your body's cells that involve attaching sugar molecules to proteins. Mutations in ATP6VOA2 can also cause autosomal recessive cutis laxa syndrome type 2 (ARCL type 2). Some consider wrinkly skin syndrome to be a mild variant of ARCL type 2.[4476][12629][12630]

references.authors: Morava E, Guillard M, Lefeber DJ, Wevers RA
references.articleTitle: Autosomal recessive cutis laxa syndrome revisited.

references.authors: Van Maldergem L, Dobyns W, Kornak U
references.articleTitle: ATP6V0A2-Related Cutis Laxa

references.authors: Arora P, Chakravarty P, Khanna D, Gupta R
references.articleTitle: Cutis laxa autosomal recessive type II or wrinkly skin syndrome?

references.authors: Guillard M, Lefeber DJ, Morava E, Wevers RA
references.articleTitle: Wrinkly skin syndrome

gardCases.abbreviatedInquiry: I am looking for more information on wrinkly skin syndrome; its symptoms, body changes, treatment, what to expect, effects on different ages, and cases.

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.

phenoTypes.phenoTypeName: Excessive skin wrinkling on dorsum of hands and fingers
Abnormal isoelectric focusing of serum transferrin
Delayed closure of the anterior fontanelle
Fragmented elastic fibers in the dermis
Slender long bones with narrow diaphyses
Neonatal wrinkled skin of hands and feet
